text: A tetrahedron or triangular pyramid is a polyhedron (a three-dimensional shape). It has four corners and six edges. All four of its faces are equilateral triangles. Every two edges meet on one of those corners forming a sixty-degree angle. == Formulas for a regular tetrahedron == A regular tetrahedron is a tetrahedron whose edges are the same length. If the length of an edge is a: Surface areaCoxeter, Harold Scott MacDonald; Regular Polytopes, Methuen and Co., 1948, Table I(i) {\sqrt{3}}a^2\, Face area \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}a^2\, HeightKöller, Jürgen, "Tetrahedron", Mathematische Basteleien, 2001 \sqrt{\frac23}\,a\, and \frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}a Volume \frac{a^3}{6\sqrt{2}}\, and \frac{\sqrt{2}}{12}a^3 == Other properties == A regular tetrahedron's faces are all the same, and so are all its edges, as well as its corners. This makes it a regular polyhedron. It is also convex (its faces do not go through one another), which makes it a Platonic solid. The dual of regular tetrahedron is another regular tetrahedron. This is called being self-dual. ==References== Category:Platonic solids
title: Tetrahedron
